utterance: how can i disconnect from a websocket automatically when no component using it in the dom?

speaker: lihaibh
utterance: i dont want to hold many websockets because its resource consuming

speaker: lihaibh
utterance: or atleast thats what i think it is, correct me if im wrong

speaker: lihaibh
utterance: i want kind of lazy usage of websockets is it possible?

speaker: babeal
utterance: lihaibh: use the websocket subject in rxjs or wrap your websocket into an observable and share it

speaker: lihaibh
utterance: and how would i know when to disconnect?

speaker: babeal
utterance: when all subscribers unsubscribe then the dispose function will be executed as long as you “share” it.  I think share has been removed so you would need to run .publishReplay(1).refcount().

speaker: lihaibh
utterance: publishReplay? not regular 'publish'?

speaker: babeal
utterance: I had to implement an operator that delayed the dispose though, because since changing routes will destroy the components before the new ones are created and the websocket connection will be torn down.

speaker: babeal
utterance: It’s to share only 1 version of the websocket

utterance: Hi All, I need to have a tabs in my app. each tab will load its own component. so there would be parent component which will have 3 tabs and each tab will load its own component when user clicks on it. any solution to achieve this ?

speaker: HauntedSmores
utterance: vishalgajjar: Exactly what you just said lol

speaker: HauntedSmores
utterance: Just make the tabs with routerLinks

speaker: HauntedSmores
utterance: and a <router-outlet> underneath

speaker: vishalgajjar
utterance: HauntedSmores: there is already one router-outlet in the application so how to target the child router-outlet.?

speaker: HauntedSmores
utterance: vishalgajjar: You may need to structure your app a little differently. You cant have more than one router outlet in a single component

speaker: HauntedSmores
utterance: vishalgajjar: Lets say you have Component A with its child component, Component B, which will hold the tabs

speaker: HauntedSmores
utterance: vishalgajjar: Then you have one <router-outlet> that pulls in your top level components. INSIDE component A you have another <router-outlet> That pulls in and routes to your different tabs

utterance: Divya-tfw: : First u have to collect all the contacts in an ArrayList. and compare if that array list is sorted.

speaker: pramodnaik
utterance: Divya-tfw: : Example for checking sortedboolean checkSorting(ArrayList< String > arraylist){boolean isSorted=true;for(int i=1;i < arraylist.size();i++){if(arraylist.get(i-1).compareTo(arraylist.get(i)) > 0){isSorted= false;break;}}return isSorted;}

utterance: The 'parent' container has the host docker socket bound (-v /var/run/docker.sock:) so when the agent (parent container) tries to run a new container and pass some -v flags; the -v flags don't get mounted correctly as far as I can tell

speaker: galvesribeiro
utterance: cluster in node is not a real cluster

speaker: galvesribeiro
utterance: it is just a proxy/main process which spawn other process and forward requests to be processed there

speaker: galvesribeiro
utterance: node (because of V8 and libUV) has a single thread

speaker: galvesribeiro
utterance: so each node.exe process is 1 single thread

speaker: galvesribeiro
utterance: what cluster does is multiplex that thread with diff process at cost of serialization and marshaling between process

speaker: galvesribeiro
utterance: so you basically have 1+CPUThreadCount node processes per machine

speaker: galvesribeiro
utterance: this is their cluster

speaker: xuzhongxing
utterance: AlexDBlack: alex could you please explain the meaning of iteration number in the BasicRNNExample?

speaker: AlexDBlack
utterance: suppose you have 3 examples: A,B,C in a DataSetIterator.iterations(1): fit(DataSetIterator) does training like ABC.iterations(3): fit(DataSetIterator) does training like AAABBBCCC

speaker: AlexDBlack
utterance: usually .iterations(1) is what you want

speaker: AlexDBlack
utterance: that was an example contributed by the community fwiw

speaker: xuzhongxing
utterance: thank you.

speaker: xuzhongxing
utterance: So in that example, it is similar to the epoch parameter

speaker: AlexDBlack
utterance: if all data is in one DataSet object: then .iterations(x) and fitting for x epochs are identical

speaker: AlexDBlack
utterance: in general, similar to epochs, but different order

speaker: AlexDBlack
utterance: repeated order like that isn't usually a good idea

speaker: xuzhongxing
utterance: I see.

speaker: xuzhongxing
utterance: In what situation setting iterations > 1 makes sense?

speaker: AlexDBlack
utterance: not many, to be honest. full batch/dataset learning (usually only possible on very small data sets), andmaybeif data loading is very costly

speaker: xuzhongxing
utterance: I see

speaker: JosephCatrambone
utterance: daredemo: There are small special things for each of the subtypes of autoencoders.  Sparse has a penalty (usually L1) which encourages sparse activation in the inner-most hidden layer.  Denoising adds noise on the input and attempts to reconstruct a noise free output.  Variational autoencoders instead learn a mean and standard deviation instead of an explicit internal state, then randomly generate a hidden state from those values and reconstruct.

speaker: JosephCatrambone
utterance: Of the bunch, denoising is perhaps the easiest to train, since you just had to do train(myExamples + noise, myExamples)

utterance: Guys help please. I don't understand what each gate in LSTM architecture produce. Is it a number or a vector? speaker: AlexDBlack
utterance: each gate produces a single number in range 0 to 1. you have 4 gates per LSTM unit, and multiple units per LSTM layer

speaker: fahman
utterance: Is number of units == LSTM.nOut(numberUnits) of layer actually?

utterance: fahman: yes

speaker: borjka
utterance: by LSTM block I mean LSTM unit

speaker: AlexDBlack
utterance: borjka: yes, it's the same as any other RNN (or, any other network in general) - each unit gives a single output/number

speaker: AlexDBlack
utterance: it's all vectorized for implementation though, across all units

utterance: Hi, I've been trying to sync mist wallet but the last 500,000 blocks take forever. for the past 2 days it only syncs 30,000 blocks/day. speaker: beaver25
utterance: petrosmit :  open a command promp and and type

speaker: beaver25
utterance: cd  C:\Users\yourusername\AppData\Roaming\Ethereum Wallet\binaries\Geth\unpacked\geth-windows-amd64-1.5.2-c8695209

speaker: beaver25
utterance: this should put you in the right folder where geth is then type

speaker: beaver25
utterance: geth removedb this will delete the block chain

speaker: beaver25
utterance: then type

speaker: beaver25
utterance: geth --fast --cache=512 --maxpeers 75 --jitvm this should start downloading the Bock chain again from scratch and will take approx 3-5hrs depending on your connection speed

speaker: beaver25
utterance: DON't open Mist or the ether wallet (depending on witch one your using ) until it completly finishes . Sometimes it may get stuck and if you stop it syncing and then restart it ,it will not download quick (fast) and slows right down. The fast command does not work if it sees that you have some of the Block chain , you have to delete the Block chain and start again

speaker: beaver25
utterance: The first 750,000 blocks should download in approx 30 mins on a T2 Fibre connection and then it does slow down but that is more the fact that there is bigger blocks . Also at about 2,870,000 you may notice it 's downloading the  file structure witch is 19 million + (not shore if it's actually Blocks or just data) and will take about 2 hrs , the Block chain as of today  is 15 gig  so it does take some time and the slower your connection is the longer it will take

speaker: petrosmit
utterance: @beaver25  Thank you so much for your input.  I do as you say , i deleted the db and run the command but after 5 mins it stops. this is the last thing that shows: goroutine 21658 [select]:github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/p2p.(Peer).pingLoop(0x40e75b90)        C:/gopath/src/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/p2p/peer.go:199 +0x1dbcreated by github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/p2p.(Peer).run        C:/gopath/src/github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/p2p/peer.go:146 +0x17fany idea why and what should i do now? In addition is there a fast way i can deploy contracts (to test-net) without downloading the whole chain? i want to use for my master thesis project. Thanks in advance

speaker: beaver25
utterance: petrosmit  : what version of Mist or wallet are you using ?  If you have geth version 1.4.11 you will need to use this command line after you delete the block chain and start again : geth --fast --support-dao-fork --cache=512 --maxpeers 75 --jitvm  i have had trouble when i have not used the --support-dao-fork command so try again .  I think you can't get around not downloading the whole chain before you deploy a contract  . You could try uninstalling everything and restarting the system and then reinstall Just mist but install 0.8.7 and that way i know you will have all the right programs in the right places  . However i would remove what is in the Mist folder in c:\user\yourusertname\AppData\Local\Mist and copy the new version 0.8.8 to the Mist folder you have just deleted don't remove the folder Mist just what is inside it . You can download the new version and just unzip it to any folder you wish , it's the contents of the folder you copy and paste to your Mist folder in C:\users\yourusername\AppData\Local\Mist . Don't run Mist until you have  replaced the Mist contents with the new versionif you do it this way don't run geth  just run Mist and let it download . If you still having trouble i would check your connection to see if it's dropping out and contact your ISP .remember if you stop it from downloading you will have to start from scratch as the second time you start it it will not download fast if you have not deleted the chain

utterance: @BluscreamDMCA has no relevance for community names. DMCA is specifically for content violations where circumvention of rights management is being distributed such as PirateBay, KAT (closed as a result of a DMCA case & arrest), Popcorn Time etc...It criminalizes production and dissemination of technology, devices, or services intended to circumvent measures (commonly known as digital rights management or DRM) that control access to copyrighted works.if there's a name violation that's infringing on a trademark infringement a legal precedent would need to be established if the use is happening beyond Gitter. if the use is unique to Gitter, evidence of a registered trademark and infringement would need to be established.

speaker: Z3roCoder
utterance: Hi@all, I have a important question about the Interfacing in Typescript.Why does this example act like it does? Shouldn't test2,3 and 4 throw errors? [<-CODE->]

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: Z3roCoder: you should wrap your code in ```

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: so it's readable

speaker: Z3roCoder
utterance: There we go :)

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: interfaces aren't exclusive

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: they only require properties be there

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: it doesn't care about extra properties

speaker: Z3roCoder
utterance: But in case 2 and 3, it requires exactly the properties in the interface

speaker: Z3roCoder
utterance: b is not in the interface, and this it complains that b shouldnt be there

speaker: Z3roCoder
utterance: [<-LINK->]

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: return{a : 3 b:3}satisfies the interface

speaker: Z3roCoder
utterance: Look at my screenshot

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: oh ... on object literals yeah

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: you need to do any on object literals if you want it to work

speaker: Z3roCoder
utterance: So this is expected behaviour?

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: yes

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: it's mostly designed for when you are passing object literals to function

speaker: Z3roCoder
utterance: When is, and when isn't, something a object literal in my example?

speaker: Z3roCoder
utterance: Isn't <ITest>{ a: 3, b: 3 }; also a object literal?

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: yeah but then you are casting it specifically to an ITest

speaker: Z3roCoder
utterance: So what's the difference then betweenreturn <ITest>{ a: 3, b: 3 };andconst c: ITest = { a: 3, b: 3 } (This complains)

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: what version are you using?

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: So the thinking is if you are setting extra properties you'll never be able to safely access them from the interface that you are assigning

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: so the compiler assumes this is likely an error on your part

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: and you have to use type assertion to get around it

speaker: Z3roCoder
utterance: Why would this not apply to test4 then? This is basically the same example as test3, only that in this case, a Promise of the type ITest is returned

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: probably an edgecase the compiler does not consider

utterance: Alright, i will write a issue about this then

utterance: Maybe then it will become clearer

utterance: if you don't get a compile time error with typescript that means typescript has found it

utterance: but typescript search paths might not always equate to webpack settings, so a lot of times webpack settings need to be tweaked to match

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: usually only the case if you are using path mapping or multiple source roots in typescript

speaker: Matmo10
utterance: Given this: [<-CODE->] Why does this cause an error: [<-CODE->] But this does not: [<-CODE->]

speaker: Matmo10
utterance: TS2365: Operator '===' cannot be applied to types 'TemplateType.Boolean | TemplateType.Date | TemplateType.Numeric | TemplateType.Text' and 'TemplateType.Complex'.

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: Matmo10: ahh.. the dangers of javascript type coercion

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: it's actually keeping you from doing a  subtle error

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: TemplateType.Complexis equal to0

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: so when you do!templateTypeon aTemplateType.Complexit will actually return true

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: which means on the right hand side of your||templateTypewill never be able to beTemplateType.Complex

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: You should just always avoid doing shorthand!templateTypewhen you actually mean to do a null check

speaker: dtabuenc
utterance: you should always be explicit on your null checks, or you'll run into a lot of subtle js bugs.

speaker: Bnaya
utterance: ezra-quemuel: with jest (ts-jest) you can mock es6 modules

speaker: Bnaya
utterance: The trick/problem is that, when es6 modules imports are transpiled to commonjs require calls they are hoisted to the top of the file

speaker: Bnaya
utterance: babel-jest hoist your mock calls above the  require calls, but ts-jest doesn't support it yet.So what you can do is to put your jest.mock calls on a module and import first thing to your test file

speaker: Bnaya
utterance: ts-jest has other issues, like sometimes inaccurate coverage reports. but its working and super fast

utterance: ewnd9: engines could work but it doesn't seem to be used much. I'm also thinking about the use of npm for frontend modules. speaker: ewnd9
utterance: protometa: I'm fine with es5 . But as an example of a variation - somereact-nativemodules are published as is and if you need to use them in other environments you need to use only single presetbabel-preset-react-native

speaker: protometa
utterance: ewnd9: that works if you know a specific module or set of modules is pure es6 or es7 but seems like we need a more general solution for module consumers to know which version of javascript a module uses.

speaker: protometa
utterance: rather than making it a concern of newer modules to covert for older consumers the older consumers could just convert newer modules that they wish to use.

speaker: protometa
utterance: then we could all publish pure es7 modules and a platform that can run es7 isn't stuck with es5.

utterance: So I've been digging around, and I can't seem to find a planned features roadmap, so my question is, when is async/await supposed to drop?

speaker: Hesulan
utterance: palodequeso: async/await is supposed to land in v8 LTS in march, node.js won\'t get it right away, though it\'s already available behind the "--harmony" flag in node 7

speaker: palodequeso
utterance: ah, interesting, I didn't know it was available behind harmony, but March then, sweet

speaker: palodequeso
utterance: I'll plan rewrites accordingly haha

speaker: ljharb
utterance: don't use the harmony flag ever

speaker: ljharb
utterance: the async/await implementation behind the harmony flag has a ton of memory leaks and bugs

speaker: ljharb
utterance: the harmony flag is for broken features - if it was reliable in production, it'd be unflagged.

speaker: Hesulan
utterance: Harmony is for not-quite-production-ready features, horribly broken features get their own separate flags. It does have a bunch of memory leaks and bugs though, so don't use itin production.

speaker: ljharb
utterance: "production-ready" isn\'t a spectrum

speaker: ljharb
utterance: either way, the harmony flags are for testing v8. they're not meant for production use, and you're a bad person if you use them.
